item.title: [HIVE-19212] Fix findbugs yetus pre-commit checks
item.description: Follow up from HIVE-18883, the committed patch isn't working and Findbugs is still not working.
item.summary: Fix findbugs yetus pre-commit checks

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment:
Peter Vary lets try this again

It looks like when I was testing HIVE-18883 I had forgotten that I had added the --dirty-workspace parameter, which was why FindBugs was working locally.

The attached patch reverts the changes to dev-support/yetus-wrapper.sh done in HIVE-18883. Instead, I just manually installed the FindBugs package on the ptest-master. yetus-exec.vm just sets FINDBUGS_HOME to the location of the package.

I'm not a huge fan of this approach because if the ptest-master dies FindBugs will stop working unless someone remembers to re-install the FindBugs package. However, I couldn't find a better way to do this. At first I tried to add some code to install FindBugs in yetus-exec.vm if it isn't already installed, but that won't work because the hiveptest and tomcat users on the ptest-master don't have permissions to install packages via apt-get.

I'm hoping that if we move to the Docker based Yetus execution this will get cleaned up.

I have tried your patch locally without the --dirty-workspace and was working like charm. Since patchprocess directory is in .gitignore it should not matter anyway. I would prefer to stick to your original idea. Maybe Adam Szita could help us out. He knows more about the whole stuff, and might be able to easily pinpoint the issue here.

hmm thats odd, its definitely not working on the ptest machines though. The yetus logs explicitly say Removing patchprocess - e.g. http://104.198.109.242/logs//PreCommit-HIVE-Build-10204/yetus.txt

If you login to the ptest master while yetus is running and run ps aux | grep yetus it will should you the path to the yetus distribution being used. You can run ls on each of these files and see that they don't exist.

Perhaps yetus doesn't honor .gitignore?

Looks like this is the cause - https://github.com/apache/yetus/blob/2b91d243f7afbe89ec558fe09b7e33f90e065ac4/precommit/test-patch.sh#L1318

It runs git clean with the -x option, which according to https://www.atlassian.com/git/tutorials/undoing-changes/git-clean deletes files that are in .gitignore too.

The reason it works locally is because the git clean isn't triggered unless you specify the -jenkins option (which we do enable in yetus-exec.sh). Looking through the code for test-patch.sh, enabling the jenkins option also enables the -resetrepo option. Which is what triggers the git clean to run.

Sahil Takiar for temp dir you could use /data/hiveptest/working/scratch. You can still fetch findbugs into that folder and can clean it up later manually. If downloading findbugs doesn't take a lot of time I'd recommend doing that (per build) instead of depending on one installed on hiveptest-server.

item.title: [HIVE-19213] Values query: Stop opening transactions on _dummy_table
item.description:
When the query-cache is hit query is a values clause, the ACID TxnManager opens a txn + lock + heartbeats on _dummy_database._dummy_table.

This is blocking values clause from jumping through the fast-paths for transactions.
item.summary: Values query: Stop opening transactions on _dummy_table

status.description: The issue is open and ready for the assignee to start work on it.

comments.comment: This turned out to be related to metadata optimizer than the query-cache.

transactions are opened before the query is analyzed so you can't skip that (w/o adding a hack).
We have Entity.Type.DUMMYPARTITION. If we can add Type.DUMMTABLE, the lock manager can easily skip acquiring locks for this resource.

item.title: [HIVE-19214] High throughput ingest ORC format
item.description: Create delta files with all ORC overhead disabled (no index, no compression, no dictionary). Compactor will recreate the orc files with index, compression and dictionary encoding.
item.summary: High throughput ingest ORC format

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment: Gopal V can you please take a look? small patch.

Block-padding to false - the padding is irrelevant for the small stripe flushing & is just wasting space.

LGTM +1

-1 overall

ATTACHMENT ID: 12919041 - PreCommit-HIVE-Build
this makes changes to OrcRecordUpdate w/o checking if it's doing streaming ingest - is that what we want?
i am not sure if sorted dynamic partition optimization works with ACID or not. This will help non-streaming cases as well, helps reduce memory pressure when a single task writes/reads many files.

SDPO should work, though that is orthogonal. If you have a simple Insert into an acid table, this would likely make reads suboptimal and so requires much more frequent compactions. This may be justified in streaming (esp w/dynamic partitions) but it's not in all cases. For example, if you have a table that is infrequently written to by large insert statements it may not need any compactions at all (unless you make this change as is) . There should be some config that can be set control this at least at table level though would be better per statement/connection.
Make sense. Will put this under a config. Default disabled for non-streaming and default enabled for streaming cases.

Added the changes under config.
PPD changes when no stripe stats are available for delta files.
LLAP IO changes to deal with no row indexes and hence no positional information (treat this as entire column read)
Gopal V can you please take another look? For streaming, will enable it by default in the new endpoint API.

LGTM - +1

Consider renaming the ".throughput." to just ".streaming." so that is obvious.
Renamed throughput to streaming

-1 overall

item.title: [HIVE-19216] beeline: initscript commands should not be recorded in the history
item.description: I've about 10 settings changed in my initscript; it makes my history barely useable - since every time I launch a new session all the set commands are recorded in the history....
item.summary: beeline: initscript commands should not be recorded in the history

status.description: The issue is open and ready for the assignee to start work on it.

item.title: [HIVE-19217] Upgrade to Hadoop 3.1.0
item.description: Upgrade to Hadoop 3.1.0
item.summary: Upgrade to Hadoop 3.1.0

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment: Opened with 10 min difference

item.title: [HIVE-19219] Incremental REPL DUMP should throw error if requested events are cleaned-up.
item.description:
This is the case where the events were deleted on source because of old event purging and hence min(source event id) > target event id (last replicated event id).

Repl dump should fail in this case so that user can drop the database and bootstrap again.

Cleaner thread is concurrently removing the expired events from NOTIFICATION_LOG table. So, it is necessary to check if the current dump missed any event while dumping. After fetching events in batches, we shall check if it is fetched in contiguous sequence of event id. If it is not in contiguous sequence, then likely some events missed in the dump and hence throw error.
item.summary: Incremental REPL DUMP should throw error if requested events are cleaned-up.

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

This closes #334

commit b883f8b28c9f86e0cc731bc1b43c3706617bec81
Author: Sankar Hariappan <mailtosankarh@...>
Date: 2018-04-16T16:05:46Z

HIVE-19219: Hive replicated database is out of sync if events are cleaned-up.

Added 01.patch

  • REPL DUMP throw IllegalStateException if events found missing in source.
  • Modified testIncrementalLoadWithVariableLengthEventId to rename the dumped event directory names instead of changing event id while dumping.

Attached 02.patch with change in logic

  • If last replicated event is missing from NOTIFICATION_LOG table, then shall assume some events might be missing from dump and throw error.
  • Validate this after dumping all the events to confirm if events not deleted concurrently when dumping in progress.
  • No constraint to get events in sequence.

Request mahesh kumar behera to review it!

Attached 03.patch

  • Fallback to original logic of checking if events are obtained in contiguous sequence. Verifying last replicated event may not be right as eventTime and eventId won't be in same sequence. So, cleaner may remove events not in sequence.
  • Fixed all comments from Mahesh.

Request mahesh kumar behera to review it!

The code changes looks fine

item.title: [HIVE-19220] perfLogger = SessionState.getPerfLogger() in Driver.java need to combine
item.description:
I find  duplicate code in Driver.java. We need to eliminate duplicate code to improve the simplicity of the code

 

Before modification

PerfLogger perfLogger = null;
if (!alreadyCompiled) {
 // compile internal will automatically reset the perf logger
 compileInternal(command, true);
 // then we continue to use this perf logger
 perfLogger = SessionState.getPerfLogger();
} else {
 // reuse existing perf logger.
 perfLogger = SessionState.getPerfLogger();
 // Since we're reusing the compiled plan, we need to update its start time for current run
 plan.setQueryStartTime(perfLogger.getStartTime(PerfLogger.DRIVER_RUN));
}

 

After  modification 

 

PerfLogger perfLogger = SessionState.getPerfLogger();

      if (!alreadyCompiled) {
        // compile internal will automatically reset the perf logger
        compileInternal(command, true);
      } else {
        // Since we're reusing the compiled plan, we need to update its start time for current run
        plan.setQueryStartTime(perfLogger.getStartTime(PerfLogger.DRIVER_RUN));
      }
item.summary: perfLogger = SessionState.getPerfLogger() in Driver.java need to combine

status.description: This issue was once resolved, but the resolution was deemed incorrect. From here issues are either marked assigned or resolved.

item.title: [HIVE-19221] DESC FORMATTED shows incorrect results in table statistics for full ACID table after multi table inserts
item.description:
"DESC FORMATTED acid_table" seems to show incorrect table row count and COLUMN_STATS_ACCURATE item values after multi table inserts.

I will add the test case shortly.
item.summary: DESC FORMATTED shows incorrect results in table statistics for full ACID table after multi table inserts

status.description: The issue is open and ready for the assignee to start work on it.

item.title: [HIVE-19222] TestNegativeCliDriver tests are failing due to "java.lang.OutOfMemoryError: GC overhead limit exceeded"
item.description: TestNegativeCliDriver tests are failing with OOM recently. Not sure why. I will try to increase the memory to test out.
item.summary: TestNegativeCliDriver tests are failing due to "java.lang.OutOfMemoryError: GC overhead limit exceeded"

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment: Siddharth Seth I saw you decreased the memory setting for the tests. Wondering if you have any insights on the memory increase requirement for TestNegativeCliDriver. I couldn't figure out on my side.

Aihua Xu - the memory decrease would likely have been a result of running with smaller values, which should be good enough for tests. So - no specific insight into what may have caused the increase / OOM.

It started failing relatively recently compared to the memory decrease.
I wonder if a better approach might be adding a memory dump on OOM GC setting, and dumping into the logs directory. Then we can see what's taking up the space...

Also btw I wonder if we should migrate most negative tests to a much smaller number of positive tests using set hive.cli.errors.ignore=true;
See e.g. resourceplan.q that tests negative and positive cases together using that.
That way we can reduce the # of tests and thus the setup/teardown overhead.
cc Ashutosh Chauhan
Sergey Shelukhin That's good to know. We can group errors into fewer tests. HIVE-19000 has a little more insights.
Is there a heapdump collected somewhere on the test machines?
Created HIVE-19223 to track the test migration. That is a good idea.
I will test this change to workaround the issue if it works since it's blocking the commit. At the meantime we can find out root cause and revert this.

-1 overall

Ashutosh Chauhan, Sergey Shelukhin, Gopal V Increasing the memory can workaround the issue and we can focus on the real failures. Do you think we should commit this?

Yeah.. I think so. 1 GB memory should be sufficient to run -ve tests, so it does look like there is a leak. But having tests fail on every run is not useful either. So, lets get this in. We can use HIVE-19000 for leak.
Pushed to master. Thanks, Aihua!
Pushed to branch-3 as well

item.title: [HIVE-19223] Migrate negative test cases to use hive.cli.errors.ignore
item.description: Migrate the negative test cases to use hive.cli.errors.ignore properties so multiple negative tests can be grouped together. It will save test resources and execution times.
item.summary: Migrate negative test cases to use hive.cli.errors.ignore
